text: Lactobacilli and vaginal host defense : activation of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 long terminal repeat , cytokine production , and NF-kappaB .

Lactobacilli , a component of the normal vaginal flora , can activate the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) in the Jurkat T lymphocyte and THP-1 macrophage cell lines .
Activation of the LTR in Jurkat cells was strongly enhanced by vanadate and inhibited by <extra_id_0> catalase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , implicating H2O2 .
In contrast , activation in THP-1 cells occurred in the absence of vanadate and was unaffected by <extra_id_0> catalase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
The active material partitioned into the phenol layer on hot aqueous phenol extraction .

Lactobacilli also increased <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> interleukin-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production and activated NF-kappaB in THP-1 cells and increased <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by human monocytes .

text: Human vaginal fluid specimens had comparable properties , which correlated with their bacterial content .

These findings suggest the presence in vaginal fluid of agent ( s ) derived from indigenous bacteria that can activate the HIV-1 LTR , cytokine production , and NF-kappaB in cells of macrophage lineage , with possible influence on vaginal physiology and host defense .
